job_title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker LCSW in Brooklyn, NY

job_title: Social Worker LMSW in Bronx, NY

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY

job_title: Care Manager in Bronx, NY

job_title: Professional Support Staffer in Brooklyn, NY
pros: There are a lot of friendrly people who work at Brightpoint and the pay is as good or better than a few other places but competitive with most.  The atmosphere is generally cheery and there is free coffee and tea all day.  If you are a workaholic or like giving free labor, you've found your niche.
cons: Unfortunately, it operates like a sweat shop and almost every position has much more work than anyone can accomplish during a typical work day.  Managers seem to be disorganized and clueless about daily operation of an office and there seems to be zero policy and procedures in place to refer to for particular units.  The agency also expects employees to put on a happy  face but management discourages people from taking breaks and gives only a half hour lunch.

job_title: Graphic Designer in New York, NY
pros: Everyone is extremely welcoming. Very diverse staff. Everyone is friendly. Beautiful headquarters office space. Great tea. Popcorn everyday. Great office environment
cons: Extremely unorganized. Bad server systems kept crashing. I'm terribly disappointed in this company. They hired me in February I started in March. I would start a project and be told in the middle of my project to stop what I was doing to work on another project. Then told to stop that 2nd project to yet work on another project. Wasn't given the creative liberty to work on a project to completion at all and wasn't given great feedback. No constructive criticism. If my project wasn't what was wanted I was told "it's not quite right" but not told how and why and what I can do to make it better. Only a month into my employment my entire department was called in by the CEO and HR and told they knew since December they were having money issues and told us they couldn't afford us. Told us we were terminated on the spot! Why would you hire me then?! Plus they gave me 5k above the salary they initially budgeted for. They have poor budgeting and accounting skills!

job_title: Program Manager in Jamaica, NY
pros:
Teams work together decent 
Collaboration innovation
cons: None it was a great job

job_title: Dentist in Bronx, NY
pros: Excellent and appreciative patient population
cons: Culture has changed and is not patient centric

job_title: Credentialing Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Do not bother wasting your time at this company.  They sell a piper's dream and as soon as you accept and start working you realized that the company stands for everything opposite of what was told.  In my work history I have never seen a company ran like this.  No one seems to know what they are doing, there is no structure or order, employees dip as they please.  This company is a revolving door people do not stay long as soon as they find out out disorganized and trashy the company is they leave.  Save yourself the time and aggravation and look elsewhere I would not recommend this company to my my enemy no matter how desperate they are to find a job no one deserve to be treated like a second class citizen.
cons: There are no cons just plain dry, boring and disorganized.

job_title: Social Worker in Epsom, England
pros: Rapidly growing non-profit, with ever present opportunities for growth as a professional. Diverse population of communities served, and diverse staff. Supportive work environment. Good benefits package for full-time workers. Fulfilling, meaningful work, and the opportunity to to be a supportive figure in the lives of many traditionally under-served New Yorkers. Fun team-building activities and employee recognition perks.
cons: Some departments would benefit from increased staff support. Changes in Medicaid payment structure as well as the economy overall have resulted in the organization being forced to transfer ownership of the residential healthcare facility to another organization.

job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: Salary and benefits are competitive. Most co-workers are easy to deal with. The main office in Chelsea is streamlined but comfortable.
cons:
A number of things regarding how Brightpoint Health is run, need to be fixed. The biggest problem is organization. This place suffers from major disorganization--from IT to External Relations. There are often technical problems with the company website, in-house software, etc., which can take all day, or longer, to fix.

Upper management overall needs major improvements. Some people in administrative positions who have creative skills are not allowed a chance to use these talents. Instead, money is wasted on overpriced "consultants" and freelancers. Call me an old yenta, but after reading some of these, obviously phony, reviews, I felt I needed to speak up.

job_title: Representative in New York, NY
pros: The pay was decent and the benefits are good. Lots of room for advancement for the ethically challenged. Nice branding.
cons:
Unethical. Poor leadership. Mismanaged. 

Discrimination against and refusal to serve undocumented immigrants and self-pay clients.

Enrolling clients in unnecessary services--sales reps earn per capita commission for each service they connect a patient to. Sales reps provide kickbacks to referral sources at shelters and drug treatment programs in exchange for referrals to help them make their numbers.

The organization exploits the homeless by promising them housing if they enroll in a medicaid care management program. After patient completes enrollment and the organization begins to receive a per member per month fee from Medicaid they are informed the organization does not in fact assist with accessing housing programs. Patients tend to disengage from services without disenrollment allowing the organization to continue to bill Medicaid.

Patients herded into clinics like cattle from shelters. Not unusual for a patient to arrive at 8:30am and leave at 5pm without having been triaged.

job_title: Account Manager in Bronx, NY
pros: Flexible schedule, Plenty of sick/personal/vacation time, great benefits, company outings are great
cons: Commission was never paid on time and was inaccurate, account managers are treated as if working in a sweat shop  for  the organization to bring in more clients  in order to increase revenue for the company, management is poor and rude- HR received complaints and they were pushed under the rug,  Account Managers would work around the clock to meet monthly quotas- no work/life balance, constant change of workflow and structure- causing an immense amount of confusion within the departments and lack of quality care to the clients

job_title: Call Center Agent in New York, NY
pros: Family oriented with co workers, good benefits, Supervisor  is understanding . A bit harsh at times, but is needed to be a better agent with certain calls. I believe is called " Tough Love" family oriented and open to ideas, critics and changes, positive mind to become better at what we do
cons: Lack of communication within other departments. Which makes our job difficult as a call agent. Other co workers are focused on what others do instead of becoming better themselves

review_title: They want you to be a client
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bronx, NY
pros: Basically you don't do anything as a driver you pick up the clients drop them at the medical facility and wait lot of free time on your hands
cons: The pay they think that $15 an hour is a great deal of money when they only give you seven point five hours which average is about 3 or $400 a week

review_title: The company is pretty great... Looking back
job_title: Senior Care Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Benefits are top notch. 
C-suite people actually care and are accessible. 
They pay a lot of attention to a positive company culture (it does get a little absurd sometimes though). 
Senior management is stellar (middle management... Not so much).
cons:
When I left, pay was significantly under market, and there was no raise (or even talk of one) after reviewing a new license and credentials (which were worth over another 30k at other companies)   

During the rapid expansion, there were serious growing pains that caused many people to quit.

While the program directors have been incredible from my experience. Many of the supervisors they hired are under credentialed, lack required skills, or at worst are completely incompetent (a particularly well skilled subordinate shouldn't have to nor be able to do your job and their job at the same time)  

Exceptional performance is not rewarded, and there's actually surprisingly little room for growth in a fairly large agency (however, they do a good job of not taking advantage of the overzealous). They're also very skittish about promoting supervisors from within (which i vaguely understand) but that causes serious issues, and kills room for advancement.  

Despite their best efforts, there's little or no coordination between different departments (even when that coordination is crucial, for example, care coordination and clinics.) 

Even when you're highly disgruntled, they still push you into doing lengthy culture trainings (although, now I work for a company with no culture, and i miss brightpoint.) 

When I left, HR was understaffed and was not on the ball. It was improving when i left though.

job_title: Call Center Agent in New York, NY
pros: I am a current call center rep at Brightpoint I do not understand the complaints the cordinator and supervisor are very understanding and understand that as a mother of 2 children that my kids come first. They are always there to assist with any questions and do not micromanage us. They work very hard to make sure we have all the information needed to succeed withing the company.
cons: That we are never able to reach someone in the clinics and medication are being sent late to our patients this causes for us to receive alot of return calls.

review_title: Merger  and the values have changed
job_title: Care Manager in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Median Pay, work environment, ample sick/vacation time
cons: Micromanaging, lack of benefits, no communication between departments and staff. Morals and values out the window as time goes on. Numbers are the only thing that matters, even when numbers are good. have told us to spend less time with clients although they need assistance. Overworked for no benefits. No salary reviews or opportunities to improve. Plenty of training offered but so busy "making numbers" that you feel burdened to attend them.

job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: They are on time with your check. They have benefits as long as you have a pulse.
cons:
No overtime, no one stays long enough to get benefits because of harsh environemnt.
They hire people with criminal records no background check. These are the people you work with.
Egotistic senior management.
High stress and not from the clients. 
Budgeting is poor.
Training is done by high school dropouts or foreign educated minorities.
Titles are often switched to bolster company image but its all smoke.
Never in my career have I seen such in organization, fluff about "core values" and beratement of people being harassed in the fielf by management that is "Here for you"

job_title: Health Professional in Bronx, NY
pros: I thoroughly enjoyed my time as a Bright point employee. From the top of it's leadership, throughout the organization I found even in the most difficult of times Bright Point put the patient first. If you like a high paced, stimulating and caring environment Bright Point is the place for you!
cons: Needed to move out of the five boroughs, only wish Bright Point had a larger reach so that I could continue to work there.

review_title: Growing quickly, but still focused on core values.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great leadership.  Annual staff appreciation picnic and holiday party.  Our ELT team is still focused on the mission and Vision.  The CEO still has weekly lunches with new staff to gather feedback on all aspects of their hire.  Small items such as this are very important to him!!!
cons: Growing a bit too quickly, which can always be a challenge.

job_title: Provider in New York, NY
pros: Timely pay. Generous vacation, personal, sick and holiday time.
cons: Sometime during the past 3 years, Brightpoint lost its focus on quality care and only focused on quantity of NEW patients served by the Agency. Primary Care Providers have become secondary to Business Development. Despite being an FQHC, few residents from the surrounding community are actually served. Business Development busses in new residents of homeless shelters that the Agency has a contract with to obtain physical exams and psychiatric evaluations as required by the shelters. While this raises the number of new patients served, existing patients suffer in contrast. Patients are double and triple booked and walk in’s are encouraged resulting in extensive waiting times to see providers. Referrals to specialists take an exhorbitant amount of time to complete and providers frequently see a patient for a follow up before that patient even has an appointment with the specialist. Electronic prescriptions are routinely sent to the wrong pharmacy or not sent at all. The Agency’s ADHC day Program has been expanded to include a broader range of clients to increase quantity. Primary Care providers are regularly reminded of the need to minimize time with patients. As for new patients, insurance eligibility is first checked at the reception desk upon arrival rather than before. Patients for mental health providers routinely show without the needed referral or are already in treatment at another facility and are brought in by Business Development solely to increase the number of patients served. All this results in a very stressed, inefficient, chaotic work environment where front desk personnel and laboratory med techs take the brunt of the anger; yelling, screaming, and cursing from the patients. Staff burnout and turnover is high. Lunch is 30 minutes if you can actually take it  since providers are required to see every patient on their schedule scheduled prior to their  lunch break time including same day walk ins. 3 years without a raise or evaluation. Recently, a merit raise was allegedly given but it appears to have been nothing more than a 2% across the board increase with no recognition for quality of work performed or dedication to the company. Most recently, Brightpoint was acquired, “merged” officially, with another health care provider, Hudson River Health Care. The results of the merger will be seen over time . Till then, heed the reviews.

job_title: Medical Receptionist in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Some of the wage staff were friendly but the salaried ones mostly stayed in their office. The site directors try not to handle the public by having the nurse managers or front desks deal with them.

review_title: Great Work Environment and team work
